metadata.title: Clustering With More Than Two Features? Try This To Explain Your Findings | by Mauricio Letelier | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: Clustering With More Than Two Features? Try This To Explain Your Findings
metadata.description: The best strategy to explain clustering with more than 2 features to your non-technical coworkers is not with PCA.

all_paragraphs: Imagine that you get a great job as the head of the data science team in a new E-commerce mainly focused on selling men’s clothes. You noticed that the questions were heavily focused on clustering in the interview process, and now you get why: the CEO of the company it’s pressuring the marketing area to elaborate campaigns targetting the most representative groups. The marketing team knows that you are the best fit to help them! So they set up a meeting to figure this out, after a short introduction of the situation, they quickly got to the point. “We are experts defining well-suited campaigns when we know the people we are trying to reach, but we need to first identify the most representative group of clients with a description of their behavior. Besides, we know that these 6 features — they show you the csv file — best describe our customers, could you help us?”.

You feel in your lucky day, a project pushed by the CEO that easily fits into the standard clustering examples! It seems like a quick win! But two things are bothering you, the “with a description of their behavior” and “6 features” lines keep resonating in your head, those two combined sentences are hunting you. Will you be able to solve this?.

So, why I’m writing this? Because I’m passionate about the business use cases of all machine learning applications, and in this particular topic, I’ve seen good intuitions and explainability on dimensionality reduction. Still, those techniques are not meant to explain the characteristics of each group.

Despite we will train a model, this won’t be the standard article explaining the math and discussing the better error measurements. The focus here will be thinking about the business use case around clustering!

It’s essential to establish that clustering is just a tool to achieve a determined business goal. The problem isn’t to create the best clusters (it helps, though), or just to use machine learning. The problem, in our case, is that we want to understand who our customers are.
The understanding of our customers might have great impacts, even on our company’s strategy, but for today, let’s use this just for our targeting case.

In the sections above, I assumed that you know some basic concepts, in case you don’t, I want to present my short definition of them to you. If you want to dig deeper, I will embed some resources below (here it’s a good start also).
If you know them, just skip this section.

The power of combining all these concepts can be traduced in the identification of groups that even we didn’t know existed. The algorithm’s job is to assign a tag to the entity, and when all of them get one, it’s our job to make this information valuable.

I will straight-away show you our dataset because I want to exhibit some things around it soon. It was created using Numpy and Pandas, but I won’t reveal the construction process until the end. You know that the thrilling part of understanding our customers is not knowing them at first. I know that you don’t like spoilers!
As we discussed, this dataset is thought to replicate an E-commerce, every row is referred to a particular customer. Let’s begin by understanding the features (here is the repo).
ID: Unique identifier of the customer.
n_clicks: The total number of clicks on products.
n_visits: The total number of visits to the page.
amount_spent: The total USD$ spent on products.
amount_discount: The total USD$ spent on products with a discount (this value is meant to be less or equal than amount_spent).
days_since_registration: The days that have been passed since the customer registration.
profile_information: A measurement between 0 and 100 of how much the customer has filled their profile information.

Great! Now we feel ready to start the mission that was entrusted to us. Plotly it’s great for visualization! The simplicity, the beauty, and the professional aspect of the charts are perfect for getting a better sense of our data. The px.scatter_matrix method can give us a taste of our entire dataset.

As you could know, it’s easy to interpret the results when there are 2 or even 3 features. That’s probably because our standard space representation fits in 2d or 3d charts, which (for us) makes total sense.

When the number of features surpasses the capabilities of our 3-dimensional mindset, there are still some options. We can define features like the color or the size in our charts. For example, to capture 4 of our 6 features, I will show you an example using Plotly express.

Interesting! We can see that the biggest circles are around the left-down zone. Also, we can notice a positive correlation between “n_clicks” and “n_visits.” For the “days_since_registration” feature, the color doesn’t seem to be clearly correlated with anything.
Did you feel four features are manageable? Let’s try five!

Now we can see a group in the down corner, but trying to make sense of the 3-d plot plus the color and size information is kind of overwhelming. Imagine this process after creating clusters, which add one dimension because of the label (usually added as the color), we can know for sure that this isn’t going in the right way.

This unconventional path for the exploratory data analysis using a multi-dimensional approach was to show you that it’s possible, but not a recommended one to follow. It’s hard to scale to more than six features, and it’s even harder to understand everything that’s actually happening.

Now it’s clear why having too many features is a problem. If it’s hard to see those charts for us, imagine how hard it can be to present this to others. It’s time for us to go to the next step: clustering!

Because finding the optimal amount of clusters or reducing the inertia as much as it’s possible is not the most important part today, I will show you the decision of the cluster number only based on the inertia and the “elbow rule”.
This process can be improved in so many ways, and I won’t list them here, but it’s good for you to know that creating your model should be a more rigorous process.
If you are interested in the details about the inertia just visit the Scikit-learn’s documentation.

K-Means is a distance-based algorithm. Because of that, it’s super important to normalize, standardize, or choose any other option in which the distance has some comparable meaning for all the columns. MinMaxScaler, it’s an excellent tool for it.
After scaling our dataset, we can evaluate our inertia on different cluster numbers. If we see the chart, we could say that the elbow is on 3 or 4. For simplicity, we will use 3.

We are reaching the part where we will talk about the groups that we just found, but first, it’s important to describe some differences between explaining your findings to your team versus other areas.

PCA and t-SNE are techniques to reduce the number of features in your dataset. These two algorithms can help because we can get a visualization in fewer dimensions, which will lead us to an interpretation to determine if the groups are actually well-separated. It also helps in other cases, and in this particular one is super well explained — again — on Scikit-learn’s documentation.

“Inertia is not a normalized metric: we just know that lower values are better and zero is optimal. But in very high-dimensional spaces, Euclidean distances tend to become inflated (this is an instance of the so-called “curse of dimensionality”). Running a dimensionality reduction algorithm such as Principal component analysis (PCA) prior to k-means clustering can alleviate this problem and speed up the computations.”

So why PCA and t-SNE won’t help to explain our findings? Because those algorithms are for us! We can improve the results of our model if we use them! The new variables created by them aren’t directly comparable to our original features. So, despite that this can help us, it won’t help to communicate your findings to others.
To avoid digressing too much, we won’t be applying those algorithms to our dataset, but I encourage you to try them and see what happens with the clusters!

In this section, we will finally describe what we found in a way that’s easy for everyone in the organization. To keep it simple, we can just understand our customers by the mean of their characteristics, knowing that every variable is still scaled.
Line_polar is perfectly suited to this task because a circle can handle as many variables as you want, and the lines inside are pretty intuitive!

First, it’s important to see the whole picture, to understand in context the variables that really differentiate our customers. It’s clear that “days_since_registration” and “profile_information” are similar for every group. This means that we can subtract them from our analysis.
It’s also relevant to see how many people we have in each group.

After that, it’s important to understand the behavior of our customers on every variable. For example, if you look at the label 0, you can understand that they clicked, visited, and spent on discounts a lot less than the other groups, but they’re — by far — the customer that bought the most.
I will leave the description of the other customers to you because I know you get the idea. Our job isn’t finished, though, until you present this to your marketing colleagues.
Ok, now that you have shared the results, and it’s well understood by everyone, the business use case could flourish.

Analyzing “the spender” cluster, the marketing team could say that a good strategy for them would be to recommend the most profitable products on their main page first! They seem to spend just a little time selecting their products, and we could assert that is because they really appreciate their time. You can support your new friend (line_polar) with an illustration describing your customer’s main characteristics!

Also, it’s critical to facilitate a production environment to avoid the project remaining just in a “good to know” and Excel sheets flying over the company! It’s important to integrate those flows with the recommendations of your company’s website.
If you are interested I can make a tutorial for a simple Dash application with those same charts into production. It’s a good tool to monetize the model results and to help with product adoption.
A lot more could be said, but for now, the important thing is that you must be thinking about how to create a profitable campaign and try to deploy it.

In case you’re still curious about how the data was created, I will share with you the trick to create every cluster. You can have fun checking that a lot of the ones that were meant to be some type of customer, ended up in another cluster!
I think that doing some better feature engineering and trying other algorithms might do the trick. If you have better results, share them in the comments!
As you could have noticed, the groups were meant to belong to well-defined characteristics. In real life, there will be a lot of noisy data, and the customer clusters may be much higher.
Also, the model development and the customer’s description are oversimplified. The mean isn’t the only measurement that you should be looking at.
But that’s all for today! I hope that this article will help you somehow. See you soon!
If you liked it, follow me on Medium and Linkedin. If you want to write to me, I’m recently on Twitter. I will gladly talk with you!
In case you feel like reading a little more, check out my recent posts:
Your home for data science. A Medium publication sharing concepts, ideas and codes.
Chilean 🇨🇱 | Quant Finance 📈 | Azure Data Scientist Associate ☁️ | https://www.linkedin.com/in/maletelier 👨‍💼
